title: Crataegus iracunda
text:
Crataegus iracunda, with common name passionate hawthorn, and sometimes called the <a href="stolon">stolon</a>-bearing <a href="Crataegus">hawthorn</a> is a North American species of <a href="Crataegus">hawthorn</a>. It was described in 1899 by <a href="Chauncey%20Delos%20Beadle">Chauncey Delos Beadle</a> of the <a href="Biltmore%20Herbarium">Biltmore Herbarium</a> (<a href="Biltmore%20Estate">Biltmore Estate</a>) in <a href="North%20Carolina">North Carolina</a>. Taxonomic opinions have differed about this species, and to complicate matters "<a href="Crataegus%20macrosperma">Crataegus macrosperma</a>" and various species of <a href="Crataegus%20ser.%20Populneae">"C." series "Populneae"</a> have frequently been misidentified as "C. iracunda", leading to differing statements about its geographic range. The 2015 <a href="Flora%20of%20North%20America">Flora of North America</a> considers its range to be in the southeastern U.S., restricted to the US states of <a href="Alabama">Alabama</a>, <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a>, <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>, <a href="Mississippi">Mississippi</a>, <a href="North%20Carolina">North Carolina</a>, <a href="South%20Carolina">South Carolina</a>, and <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a>.
"Crataegus iracunda" is a branching shrub or small tree rarely more than in height, sprouting from the roots and thus forming large thickets. Leaves are egg-shaped, pointed at the tips, with teeth along the edges. Flowers come in flat-topped arrays. Fruit is red or orange, sometimes with green blotches.
